questions.text: All of the following are increased in the metabolic response to surgery and trauma except
questions.solution:
The integrated response to surgical injury (first 24-48 hours)

High yield points:

  • Remember that almost every hormone/product increases except insulin, IGF-1, testosterone and T3.

questions.text: High mixed venous oxygen saturation is seen in which type of shock?
questions.solution:
High mixed venous saturations are seen in septic shock.

Normal mixed venous oxygen saturation levels are 50-70 %. Levels below 50% indicate inadequate oxygen delivery and increased oxygen extraction by the cells. This is consistent with hypovolemic or cardiogenic shock.

High mixed venous saturations (>70%) are seen in sepsis and some other forms of distributive shock. In sepsis, there is disordered utilization of oxygen at the cellular level, and arterio-venous shunting of blood at the microscopic level. Thus less oxygen is presented to the cells, and those cells cannot utilize what little oxygen is presented. Thus, venous blood has a higher oxygen concentration than normal.

questions.text: Wounds initially left open and later edges opposed by sutures, heals by
questions.solution:
Wounds initially left open and later edges opposed by sutures heals by delayed primary intention.

Healing of a wound can occur in three ways:

  1. Healing by primay intention: Also called as healing by first intention. This occurs when there is apposition of the wound edges and minimal surrounding tissue trauma that causes least inflammation and leaves the best scar. Eg: clean surgical incision.
  2. Healing by seconday intention: Wounds are left open and allowed to heal by granulation, contraction and epithelialization.
  3. Healing by tertiary intention (also called delayed primary intention): Wound initially left open and edges later opposed when healing conditions are favorable.

questions.text: The size of the catheters shown in the picture below is measured in which of the following units
questions.solution:
The size of urinary catheter is measured in French (Fr). French in foleys represents the external diameter, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter. 

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 3 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 3 mm and a diameter of 1 mm.

questions.text: A 57-year-old diabetic patient presented with a painful, malodorous, discoloured scrotum, as shown in the image. The patient was febrile and in extreme pain. Which of the following organisms is not likely to be implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Fournier's gangrene. It is a type of synergistic spreading gangrene. Clostridia botulinum does not cause synergistic spreading gangrene. Clostridium perfringens and Clostridium septicum may be associated with the infection. 

Synergistic spreading gangrene is also called subdermal gangrene or necrotising fasciitis.  A mixed pattern of organisms is responsible: coliforms, staphylococci, bacteroids, anaerobic streptococci, and peptostreptococci have all been implicated, acting in synergy.

Fournier's gangrene is a polymicrobial infection and a type of necrotising fasciitis of the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region. Risk factors include immunocompromised states such as HIV, alcoholism, diabetes, etc. 

SGLT-2 inhibitors like canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin can also cause Fournier's gangrene.

The infection may be precipitated by minor procedures in the perineal area, such as a bruise, scratch, urethral dilatation, injection of haemorrhoids, or opening of a periurethral abscess. The infection spreads along the Dartos, Scarpa's, and Colle's fascia.

Clinical features include pain out of proportion to physical examination findings, fever, prostration, and pallor. Cellulitis spreads rapidly and may be associated with eschars, necrosis, flaking skin, and crepitus.

The testis is usually not affected. It is a surgical emergency. Diagnosis is majorly clinical and very rarely made by laboratory or imaging findings. 

The sequence of events that lead to the development of gangrene are as follows:

A mixed infection of the aerobic and anaerobic bacteria  → fulminating inflammation of subcutaneous tissue →, obliterative arteritis of the arterioles that supply the scrotal skin →, gangrene. Thus, a black scrotum with crepitus is seen.

The steps in the management of this condition are:

  1. IV fluids
  2. IV antibiotics
  3. Urgent surgical excision followed by skin grafting in later stages. 

When the infection has been controlled, a vacuum-assisted dressing may be helpful. Skin grafting is essential for a patient surviving an acute episode. Abdominal wall infections are known as Meleney's synergistic gangrene.

questions.text: Which of the following is the second most common affected organ in Hydatid disease, after the liver
questions.solution:
Lung is most commom organ to get affeced after liver. 

As the parasite (Echinococcus granulosus) can colonize virtually every organ in the body, the condition can be protean in its presentation.

The liver is the organ most often affected. The lung is the next most common.

questions.text: An adolescent male with recurrent abdominal pain was diagnosed with tropical chronic pancreatitis. All of the following statements are true regarding this condition except:

choices.text: Can be due to excess consumption of tapioca
Alcohol plays a role in the etiology
Dilatation of pancreatic ducts due to intraductal stones

questions.solution:
All of the above statements are true regarding tropical chronic pancreatitis except alcohol consumption plays a role in the etiology of tropical chronic pancreatitis. 

Tropical chronic pancreatitis

It usually affects the younger generation in poor socioeconomic strata. Cassava (tapioca) ingestion as a staple diet is implicated as a causative factor due to derivatives of cyanide which require sulfur-containing amino acids for detoxification. These amino acids are not present in lower socioeconomic or malnourished individuals. Alcohol consumption is not one of the etiologies of tropical chronic pancreatitis.

The pancreas appears firm and nodular macroscopically. The ducts are dilated. There is extensive periductal fibrosis associated with intraductal calcium carbonate stones of different sizes and shapes. These stones may resemble a staghorn. Microscopically, intralobular, interlobular, and periductal fibrosis are the predominant feature. 

There is a high incidence of pancreatic cancer in these patients. The patient usually has type 1 diabetes mellites (fibrocalculous pancreatic diabetes). 

Treatment:

Medical management is the mainstay of treatment. It involves exocrine pancreatic enzyme supplementation, insulin for diabetes mellitus, and the management of malnutrition. Surgery is indicated in intractable pain and in dilated ducts with stones. The procedure of choice is the removal of stones, with a side-to-side pancreaticojejunostomy to a Roux loop.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Chronic Pancreatitis

Abdominal pain: most common symptom

  • Site:
    • If infectious foci are in the head of the pancreas, then epigastric and right subcostal pain is common;
    • If the infection is limited to the left side of the pancreas, left subcostal and back pain are seen.
  • Precipitated by food intake, thus weight loss is also seen.
  • Associated with nausea, vomiting

Exocrine insufficiency:

  • Precedes endocrine insufficiency
  • Correlates with morphological changes
  • Manifests with malabsorption symptoms: steatorrhea, diarrhea.
  • Manifests with signs and symptoms of fat-soluble vitamin deficiency, such as bleeding, osteopenia, and osteoporosis: Severe cases

Endocrine insufficiency: Diabetes mellitus

Related Pearl: Chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency: TIGAR-O classification system

Toxic-metabolic

  • Alcoholic
  • Tobacco smoking
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Chronic renal failure
  • Medications—phenacetin abuse
  • Toxins—organotin compounds (e.g., dibutyltin dichloride, DBTC)

Idiopathic

  • Early onset
  • Late onset
  • Tropical

Genetic

  • Cationic trypsinogen (PRSS1)
  • Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene (CFTR)
  • Calcium-sensing receptor (CASR)
  • Chymotrypsin C gene (CTRC)
  • Pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor gene (SPINK1)

Autoimmune

  • Type 1 autoimmune chronic pancreatitis
  • IgG4 systemic
  • Type 2 autoimmune chronic pancreatitis

Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis

  • Postnecrotic (severe acute pancreatitis)
  • Recurrent acute pancreatitis
  • Vascular diseases/ischemia
  • Radiation-induced

Obstructive

  • Pancreas divisum
  • Duct obstruction (e.g., tumor)
  • Periampullary duodenal wall cysts
  • Posttraumatic pancreatic duct scars

Related Pearl: Pancreas - Most Commons

M/C cause of acute pancreatitis: Gallstones

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis: Alcohol

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis in children: Cystic fibrosis

M/C cause of pancreatic calcification: Alcohol

M/C congenital variant: Pancreas divisum

M/C site of thrombosis in chronic pancreatitis: Splenic vein 

M/C site of pseudoaneurysm in chronic pancreatitis: Splenic artery

questions.text: The following are advantages of minimal access surgery except
questions.solution:
One of the major disadvantages of laparoscopic/ minimal access surgery is the loss of tactile feedback.

Advantages of minimal access surgery

  • Decrease in wound size
  • Reduction in wound infection, dehiscence, bleeding, herniation and nerve entrapment.
  • Decrease in wound pain
  • Improved mobility
  • Decreased wound trauma
  • Decreased heat loss
  • Improved vision

questions.text: Which is the most common radio-lucent renal stone?
questions.solution:
Uric acid stones are hard, smooth and often multiple and multifaceted. Pure uric acid stones are radiolucent.

High yield points:

  • Remember the mnemonic TIXU for radio-lucent renal stones
    • Triamterene stones
    • Indinavir
    • Xanthine
    • Uric acid
  • The most common renal stone is calcium oxalate stone
  • 90% of the renal stones are radio-opaque
  • Spiral CT is the investigation of choice for renal stones

questions.text: Name the incision marked as 6
questions.solution: The various abdominal incisions you should remember are shown in the diagram below:

questions.text: The given chest x-ray findings can be caused by all of the given conditions, except _______.
questions.solution:
The above chest x-ray is typical of pneumoperitoneum. Acute intestinal obstruction does not cause pneumoperitoneum. 

The x-ray in the question shows free air beneath both the domes of the diaphragm. Perforation of bowel viscus in any part of the gastrointestinal tract can cause pneumoperitoneum. Laparoscopy-induced and peritoneal dialysis are the iatrogenic causes and are usually managed conservatively. 

An intestinal obstruction would show multiple dilated loops on an x-ray with possible air-fluid levels. When the obstruction becomes severe and there is a perforation on chronic obstructive lesions, pneumoperitoneum may occur.

Small bowel obstruction shows -

  1. Valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) 
  2. Step-ladder or concertina effect.

Irregular haustrations are characteristic of large intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: Which of the following has a score of two in modified Alvarado scoring system for acute appendicits
questions.solution:
Right iliac fossa tenderness and WBC > 10000 carry a score of 2 in Modified alvarado scoring. Rest all carry a score of 1.

Modified alvarado scoring

Symptoms
Right ilia fossa pain 1
Nausea/ vomiting 1
Anorexia 1
Signs
Right iliac fossa tenderness 2
Fever 1
Rebound tenderness 1
Tests
WBC> 10000 2
Left shift of neutrophils 1

Score >7: Surgery is recommended

questions.text: According to the Forest classification for peptic ulcer bleed, and ulcer with black spot is which grade
questions.solution: Forrest classfication is used for endoscopic findings and rebleeding risks in peptic ulcer disease.

questions.text: There is an ipsilateral solitary lymph node 6.5 cm in size, level 2 on the right side of the neck. What would be the N staging for this patient
questions.solution:
Any regional lymph node > 6cm in head and neck cancer is N3.

Regional lymph nodes (N) in head and neck cancer
NX cannot be assessed
N0 No regional lymph node metastasis
N1 single ipsilateral, <3 cm and ENE (extranodal extension)‐negative
N2

single ipsilateral lymph node, <3 cm  and ENE‐positive; or 3-6 cm  and ENE‐negative;

or multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, <6 cm and ENE‐negative; 

 metastasis in bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, <6 cm and ENE‐negative
N2a

single ipsilateral or contralateral lymph node <3 cm and ENE‐positive; 

or single ipsilateral lymph node 3-6 cm and ENE‐negative
N2b multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, <6 cm and ENE‐negative
N2c bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, <6 cm and ENE‐negative
N3

>6 cm and ENE‐negative;

or single ipsilateral lymph node >3 cm and ENE‐positive; 

or multiple ipsilateral, contralateral or bilateral lymph nodes, with ENE‐positive
N3a >6 cm and ENE‐negative
N3b

single ipsilateral node >3 cm and ENE‐positive; 

or metastasis in multiple ipsilateral, contralateral or bilateral lymph nodes, with ENE‐positive


Note:
ENE is as determined by physical examination (eg, invasion of skin, infiltration of musculature/dense tethering to adjacent structures, or dysfunction of a cranial nerve, the brachial plexus, the sympathetic trunk, or the phrenic nerve) and supported by radiological evidence, should be present to assign a status of ENE‐positive.

questions.text: Urine mircoscopy is shown below. Identify the type of stone
questions.solution:
Urine microscopy shows enveloped shaped crystals suggestive of calcium oxalate stones.

High yield points

  • Calcium oxalate dihydrate: enveloped/ bipyramidal
  • Calcium oxalate monohydrate: dumbbell/ hourglass
  • Brushite: needle shaped
  • Struvite(Magnesium ammonium phosphate): Rectangular,coffin lid
  • Uric acid: multifaceted, irregular plates/rosettes
  • Cystine: hexagonal/benzene ring

questions.text: Brain tumors will usually present with the following symptoms except
questions.solution:
Difficulty in speech is not an usual presentation of brain tumours.

Most brain tumors will present with one or more features related to the follwing triad:

  • Raised ICP (projectile vomiting, headache)
  • Seizures
  • Focal deficit

High yield points:

  • Most common brain tumor : Metastasis
  • Most common primary brain tumor in adults: Malignant Astrocytoma (Glioblastoma multiforme)
  • Most common benign brain tumor in children : Pilocytic astrocytoma
  • Most common malignant brain tumor in children: Medulloblastoma

questions.text: Which terminal branch of the facial nerve need not be repaired with a cable graft if accidently injured during a parotidectomy?
questions.solution:
With the exception of the buccal branch, the transected facial nerve branch should be repaired immediately with a cable graft, harvested from the great auricular nerve.

The upper division of the facial nerve is frequently tortuous in its course and can be damaged unless great care is taken during perineural dissection.

It is not necessary to dissect all branches of the facial nerve competely, as adequate tumor cleareance can be achieved with a more conservative resection of the superficial lobe.

With the exception of the buccal branch, the transected nerve should be repaired immediately with a cable graft, harvested from the great auricular nerve.

  • Tragal pointer (of Conley): facial nerve lies 1cm deep and inferior to its tip.
  • Superior to the posterior belly of the digastric muscle
  • Tracing the nerve backwards from its terminal branches
  • Using nerve stimulator

Note:Tragal pointer: As the tragal cartilage is dissected free from the parotid fascia, it takaes  pointed shape in its medial aspect, which is called the “pointer”.

questions.text: Inferior parathyroid is derived from the
questions.solution:
It is very important to remember that even though the inferior parathyroid lies at a location below, it is derived from the 3rd pharyngeal pouch, whereas the superior parathyroid which lies above is derived from the 4th pharyngeal pouch.

  • One must not get confused. This is so because the thymus also develops from the 3rd pouch and it takes the associated inferior parathyroid gland with it.

High yield points:

  • Parafollicular C cells are derived from the neural crest and this is the site of origin of medullary carcinoma of thyroid.

questions.text: Name the sign that is being elicited here
questions.solution:
Percussion of the facial nerve just below the zygoma causes contraction of the ipsilateral facial muscles (Chvostek’ sign), seen in hypocalcemic tetany.

Carpopedal spasm can be induced by occlusion of the arm with a blood presssure cuff for 3 min, raised above the systolic pressure (Trousseau’s sign). 

High yeild points:

  • Troisier's sign: Enlargement of the left supraclavicular lymph node
  • Trousseau's syndrome is a medical sign involving episodes of vessel inflammation due to blood clot (thrombophlebitis) which are recurrent or appearing in different locations over time (thrombophlebitis migrans or migratory thrombophlebitis) in GI malignancy: Migratory thrombophlebitis, classically described for pancreatic malignancy.

questions.text: Thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast is called as
questions.solution:
Mondor’s disease is thrombophlebits of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall, although it has also been encounterd in the arm.

Pathognomic feature is a thrombosed subcutaneous cord, usually attached to the skin.

The only treatment required is restricted arm movements, condition subsides within a few months.

High yield points:

Peau d’ orange : French for ‘orange skin’, is seen when there is invasion of dermal lymphatics with tumor cells, seen in carcinoma. It makes it stage T4b.

questions.text: Bipedicle flap is used in reconstruction of
questions.solution:
Bipedicle flap is a ‘bucket-handle’ flap supplied from both ends. It is very useful to rebuild the lower eylid.

High yield points:

  • Remember that a bipedicle flap is used for the eyelid whereas a bilobed flap is used for the nose.

questions.text: A patient who underwent total thyroidectomy presents with bleeding at the wound site 8 hours after the surgery. This is called
questions.solution:
Reactionary hemorrhage is delayed hemorrhage (within 24 hours) and is due to dislodgement of clot by resuscitation, normalisation of blood pressure and vasodilatation. It may also be due to technical failure, such as slippage of ligature.

Primary hemorrhage occurs immediately, due to an injury (or surgery).

Secondary hemorrhage is due to sloughing of the wall of a vessel. It usually occurs 7-14 days after injury and is precipitated by factors such as infection, pressure necrosis (eg drain) or malignancy.

questions.text: Damage control surgery for blunt trauma abdomen includes all of the following except
questions.solution:
Resection anastomosis of ischemic bowel is not a part of Damage control surgery.

Damage control surgery is a staged process which is used when there is an unstable patient whose disturbed physiology hampers definitive management.

Initial focus is hemorrhage control, followed by control and limitation of contamination.

This can be achieved by simple ligation of vessels, shunting of major arteries and veins, drainage, temporary stapling off of bowel, and therapeutic packing.

Then the abdomen is closed temporarily using a plastic sheet with suction.

Patient is shifted to the ICU and further resuscitation is carried out.

Once the patient is stabilized he is taken back to the OT and definitive repair (eg; suturing of liver laceration) is done.

Related Pearl: Damage Control Surgery

Five stages of damage control surgery:

1. Patient selection
2. Control of hemorrhage and control of contamination
3. Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit
4. Deﬁnitive surgery
5. Abdominal closure

Phases of Damage Control Surgery:

Phase 0: Identification of patient for damage control surgery in emergency room
Phase 1: Emergency laparotomy to stop bleeding and prevent contamination
Phase 2: ICU care for resuscitation
Phase 3: Re-laparotomy for definitive repair

Indications for damage control surgery:

Anatomical

  • Inability to achieve haemostasis
  • Complex abdominal injury, e.g. liver and pancreas
  • Combined vascular, solid and hollow organ injury, e.g. aortic or caval injury
  • Inaccessible major venous injury, e.g. retrohepatic vena cava
  • Demand for non-operative control of other injuries, e.g. fractured pelvis
  • Anticipated need for a time-consuming procedure

Physiological (decline of physiological reserve)

  • Temperature <34ºC
  • pH <7.2
  • Serum lactate >5 mmol/L (normal is <2.5 mmol/L)
  • Prothrombin time (PT) >16 s
  • Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) >60 s
  • Blood transfusion approaching 15 units
  • Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg for >60 min

Environmental

  • Operating time >60 min
  • Inability to approximate the abdominal incision
  • Desire to reassess the intra-abdominal contents (directed relook)

questions.text: Which day of wound healing is macrophage peak usually seen?
questions.solution:
A macrophage peak is usually seen on day 3 of wound healing. Macrophages achieve significant numbers in the wound by 48 to 96 hours post-injury and remain present until wound healing is complete.

Wound healing has 3 phases. The first phase is marked by hemostasis and inflammation. Polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMN)s are the first infiltrating cells to enter the wound site, peaking at 24 to 48 hours. The second population of inflammatory cells that invade the wound are macrophages which peak in 48-96 hours. T lymphocytes routinely invade the wound and peak at about 1-week postinjury and truly bridge the transition from the inflammatory to the proliferative phase of healing.

The second phase of proliferation roughly spans days 4-12 days. Fibroblasts and endothelial cells are the last cell populations to infiltrate the healing wound. The strongest chemotactic factor for fibroblasts is PDGF (Platelet-derived growth factor).

The third phase is characterized by the maturation and remodeling of the scar which involves reorganization of previously synthesized collagen.

The phases of wound healing and the levels of infiltrating cells are represented in the graph below.

questions.text: Which of the following describes degloving injury

choices.text: Skin is stripped off the subcutaneous tissue
Skin and subcutaneos fat are stripped off the underlying fascia
Skin, subcutaneous fat and fascia stripped off underlying muscle
Muscle also is stripped off leaving exposed bone

questions.solution: Degloving injury occurs when the skin and subcutaneos fat are stripped by avulsion from its underlying fascia, leaving the neurovascular structures, tendon or bone exposed.

questions.text: What is the pressure limit for doing fasciotomy in compartment syndrome
questions.solution:
A pressure of 30mmHg or more is an indication for fasciotomy in case of compartment syndrome.

Compartment pressures can be measured using a pressure monitor and a catheter placed in the muscle compartment.

If pressures are constantly greater than 30 mm Hg or if clinical signs (pain on passive extension, severe pain, distal sensory disturbance, absent pulses) are present then fasciotomy should be performed.

High yield points:

  • There are 4 compartments in the leg (anterior, lateral, superficial and deep posterior).
  • Most common compartment involved in leg is the anterior compartment.
  • Loss of distal pulse is a late sign.

questions.text: What kind of suturing is depicted below
questions.solution:
The above image depicts continous sutures.

There are four frequently used suture techniques

Interrupted:

Continuous :

Mattress :

Subcuticular :

questions.text: Ligasure can seal vessels upto
questions.solution:
Ligasure can seal vessels upto 7mm in diameter, with an average seal time of 2-4 sec, as well as pedicles, tissue bundles and lymphatics.

  • Ligasure is a vessel sealing system that is used in both open and laparoscopic surgery.
  • It actually fuses the vessel walls to create a permanent seal and is in wide use in gynecology, colorectal surgery, urology.
  • It uses a new bipolar technology that uses the body’s collagen and elastin to both seal and divide.

questions.text: NOTES stands for
questions.solution:
Natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery (NOTES)

NOTES is a technique where surgeons enter the peritoneal cavity via endoscopic puncture of a hollow viscus.

Transvaginal NOTES cholecystectomies have been performed in humans successfully.

questions.text: What is the incidence of Hirschsprung’s disease?
questions.solution: Incidence of Hirschsprung’s disease is 1:5000.

questions.text: Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis is caused by
questions.solution:
Gadolinium containing contrast agents are usualy responsible for nephrogenic systemic fibrosis.

  • Gadolinium containing contrast agents are used in MRI.
  • They can be nephrotoxic in patients with pre-existing renal failure.
  • It causes nephrogenic systemic fibrosis, which is a life-threatening condition whereby connective tissue forms in the skin causing it to become coarse and hard.

questions.text: All of the following are absolute contraindications for MRI except
questions.solution:
Pregnancy is a relative contraindication for MRI

Note : 

Absolute contraindications 

  • Ocular metallic foreign bodies
  • Pacemakers
  • Cochlear implants
  • Cranial aneurysm clips

 

Relative contraindications

  • First trimester of pregnancy
  • Claustrophobia

questions.text: What is the investigation shown below
questions.solution:
The above image depicts ERCP.

ERCP stands for Endoscopic Retrograde CholangioPancreaticography.

It involves the use of a side veiwing endoscope which is passed through the pylorus of stomach into the second part of duodenum to visualise the papilla.

This is then cannulated, and dye is injected into the pancreatic or bile duct to visualise the pancreatic or biliary tree.

It can be therapeutic or diagnostic.

High yield points:

  • MRCP stands for Magnetic resonance CholangioPancreaticography.
  • It is a non invasive procedure using MRI
  • Therapeutic procedures cannot be done.
  • To know whether the given investigation is ERCP or MRCP look for the endoscope. If endoscope is visible in the picture it is always an ERCP, whereas in MRCP there will be no endoscope.

questions.text: What is the ideal time to stop hormone replacement therapy(HRT) before surgery?
questions.solution:
Hormone replacement therapy(HRT) and oestrogen-containing oral contraceptives should be stopped four weeks prior to surgery. The progesterone-only contraceptive pill can be continued.

Note:

  • Latest guidelines say aspirin can be continued throughout.
  • Clopidogrel should be stopped 5 days before surgery.
  • Anticonvulsant and anti-parkinson medication is continued.
  • Lithium stopped 24 hours prior.

Hormone replacement therapy(HRT) and oestrogen-containing oral contraceptives should be stopped four weeks prior to surgery.This is bailey 27th edition update.

questions.text: Laminar air flow in the operation theatre can provide how many air changes per hour
questions.solution:
Laminar airflow can provide 100-300 air changes per hour and is used in some centres for surgery involving implants, eg: joint replacements, to avoid airborne infection.

High yield points

  • The minimum air changes that are required in every OT is 15-25/h.
  • Ideal working temp in OT is 18-25 degree Celcius with a humidity of 50-60%.
  • OT is kept in positive pressure relative to surroundings.

questions.text: Significant resection of the ileum can lead to the following except

choices.text: Increased uric acid stone in kidney

questions.solution:
Increased uric acid stone in kidney is a not a complication of significant resection of the ileum.

Significant resection of the ileum can lead to short bowel syndrome which can have the following complications.

  • Peptic ulcer (gastrin hypersecretion:because the negative feedback mechanism for inhibiting gastrin secretion and reducing gastric acid production has been removed)
  • Cholelithiasis (interruption of the enterohepatic cycle of bile salts)
  • Hyperoxaluria and oxalate stones as a result of increased absorption of oxalate in the colon
  • Some patients may develop a syndrome of slurred speech, ataxia and altered affect. (fermentation of malabsorbed carbohydrates in the colon to D-lactate and absorption of this metabolite)

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the Enhanced recovery after surgery (ERAS) protocol?

choices.text: It can be used after colorectal surgery
Waiting for one week to start oral feeding
Discharge planning is started before the patient is even admitted to hospital

questions.solution:
Waiting for one week to start oral feeding is not a part of the ERAS protocol.

Enhanced recovery after surgery (ERAS) is an approach designed to speed the clinical recovery of the patient and reduce the cost and length of stay in the patient.

It is achieved by optimizing the patient's health before surgery and then delivering evidence-based best care in the perioperative period. It includes:

  • Early planned physiotherapy and mobilisation
  • Early oral hydration and nourishment
  • Adequate pain control using regular paracetamol, NSAIDs, epidural and nerve blocks
  • Discharge planning is started before the patient is admitted to hospital and involves support from stoma care nurses, physiotherapist.
  • Early removal of ryles tube and early feeding techniques

questions.text: A patient has been admitted to the ward for hernia surgery at 9am, he undergoes surgery at 12pm and is discharged by 5pm on the same day. This is called as
questions.solution:
• A day or same-day surgery is defined as one in which patient is admitted and dischared within the 12-hour day.
  • Outpatient surgery: not admitted to a ward facility.
  • Procedure room surgery: surgery not requiring full sterile theatre facilities.
  • Short stay surgery: admission of up to 72 hours.
  • Overnight stay: 23-hr admission with early morning discharge.

So in this question there is a surgery (hernia surgery), which requires admission and full sterile theatre facilities, operated within the 12 hour day period. Hence it will be a day surgery.

questions.text: All of the following are considered adjuncts to primary survery in trauma except
questions.solution:
CT scan is not an adjunct to primary survery in trauma. CT scans of the head, chest, abdomen and spine are diagnostic tests performed during the secondary survey to identify specific injuries.

Steps in ATLS philosophy

  • Primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation: identify and treat what is killing the patient.
  • Secondary survery: proceed to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care: develop a definitive management plan

Adjuncts to primary survey

  • Blood tests: full blood counts, urea and electrolytes, clotting screen, glucose, toxicology, cross match
  • ECG, pulse oximetry, ABG
  • Two wide bore cannulae for IV fluids
  • Urinary and gastric catheters
  • Radiographs of the cervical spine, chest and pelvis
  • FAST, extended focused assessment with sonography for trauma (eFAST) and DPL (Diagnostic peritoneal lavage).

FAST is a part of primary survey. Therefore option D which was earlier USG abdomen has been changed to CT scan. Option A has been changed from CBC to DPL to make the question more challenging.

questions.text: Identify the type of brain herniation marked as 1.
questions.solution:
1. Subfalcine herniation: herniation of the cingulate gyrus under the falx cerebri
  2. Herniation with midline shift
  3. Uncal herniation (uncus is part of temporal lobe)-can compress the ipsilateral third nerve
  4. Central herniation
  5. Tonsillar herniation (part of the cerebellum)

questions.text: Successful antibiotic penetration of burn eschar can be achieved with
questions.solution:
• Mafenide acetete is the antibiotic agent that penetrates burn eschar to reach the interface with the patients viable tissue.
  • It has the disadvantage that it is quite painful.
  • It is also a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and can result in metabolic acidosis.

High yield points:

  • Silver sulphadiazine: most common agent used, good activity against pseudomonas.
  • Silver nitrate (0.5%): highly effective against pseudomonas, can cause staining of all the furniture surrounding the patient.

questions.text: Identify the type of flap:
questions.solution:
This is a type of pedicled or islanded flap. Flaps are tissues that are transferred with a blood supply. Pedicled/islanded flaps: axial blood supply can be swung round on a stalk or even fully islanded so that the business end of the skin being transferred can have the pedicle buried.

Other types of flaps include:

  • Random flaps: three sides of a rectangle are used, length to breadth ratio not more than 1.5:1
  • Axial flap: much longer flaps can be used, based on known blood vessels
  • Free flaps: blood supply has been isolated, disconnected and then reconnected using microsurgery at the new site
  • Composite flap: various tissues are transferred together, often skin with bone or muscle (osseocutaneous or myocutaneous)

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for malignant melanoma except
questions.solution:
Café’ au lait spots are seen in neurofibromatosis and not in melanoma

Risk factors for developing melanoma are

  • Xeroderma pigmentosum
  • Past medical or family history of melanoma
  • Previous melanoma
  • High total number of naevi
  • Dysplastic naevi
  • Red hair
  • Tendency to freckle
  • Immunocompromised patients ( HIV, Hodgkin’s)
  • Giant congenital pigmented neavus
  • History of sunburn

questions.text: Unilateral Cleft lip repair is commonly performed at what age
questions.solution:
Unilateral Cleft lip repair : 3-6 months

Related Pearl: Timing of primary cleft lip and palate procedures:

Cleft lip alone

  • Unilateral (one side) - One operation at 3–6 months
  • Bilateral (both sides) - One operation at 4–5 months

Cleft palate alone

  • Soft palate - Only one operation at 6 months
  • Soft and hard palate - Two operations
    • Soft palate at 6 months
    • Hard palate at 15–18 months

Cleft lip and palate

  • Unilateral - Two operations
    • Cleft lip and soft palate at 5–6 months
    • Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months
  • Bilateral - Two operations
    • Cleft lip and soft palate at 4–5 months
    • Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months

Secondary management

  • Hearing, Prophylactic myringotomy, Regular audiological testing - 6–12 months

  • Speech, Velopharyngeal surgery, Speech and language therapy - 18 months

  • Orthodontic management

    - Mixed dentition - 8–10 years
    - Permanent dentition - 14-18 years

  • Excision of maxillary arch, Rhinoplasty - 16+ years

questions.text: All of the following are correct statements about carotid body tumor except

choices.text: It is seen in people who live at high altitude
10% patients have a positive family history
Carotid angiogram shows splaying of the carotid bifurcation

questions.solution:
Carotid body tumors/ chemodectoma are not hormonally active and the tumors are usually benign.

High yield points

  • It occurs in people who live at high altitude
  • Occur in the 5th decade,10% have family history
  • Slowly growing
  • Carotid angiogram shows Lyre sign (splaying of the carotid bifurcation)

questions.text: What is the 10 year patency rate of long saphenous vein grafts for CABG?
questions.solution:
• Long saphenous vein graft patency : 50-60%
  • Long term patency rates of LIMA (left internal mammary artery) : >98%
  • Radial artery : 80%

questions.text: Which type of collagen is most important in wound healing?
questions.solution:
Type III collagen is involved in wound healing.

The tensile strength of the wound is directly proportional to the amount of collagen present, and types I and III predominate in the skin and aponeurotic layers.

During healing, as disorganized collagen is degraded and reformed, covalent cross-links are formed that enhance tensile strength.

The maximum strength of the healed wound depends upon the interconnection of collagen subunits. Approximately 80 percent of the original strength of the tissue is obtained by six weeks after surgery. Wounds slowly continue to get stronger but may never achieve 100 percent of their previous strength.

Related Pearl: Types of Collagen

Collagen subtypes    Location   

Associated disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with familial adenomatous polyposis?

choices.text: Congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium

questions.solution:
Dermoid is not associated with familial adenomatous polyposis.

Familial adenomatous polyposis is associated with

  • Congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium
  • Osteoma
  • Desmoid tumor
  • Epidermoid cyst (sebaceous cyst)
  • Colorectal cancer
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps
  • Duodenal and periampullary cancer
  • Hepatobiliary tumors
  • Thyroid cancer
  • Medulloblastoma

questions.text: What procedure is being done?
questions.solution:
• The procedure that is shown is VATS: Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery.
  • Many thoracic procedures can be done through VATS like pneumonectomy, lobectomy, empyema drainage, pleural biopsy, pleurodesis.

 

High yield points

  • SILS: Single Incision Laparoscopic Surgery
  • NOTES: Natural Orifice Transluminal Endoscopic Surgery

questions.text: Most common arrhythmia seen during laparoscopy is:
questions.solution:
Most common arrhythmia created by laparoscopy is bradycardia.

A rapid stretch of the peritoneal membrane often causes a vagovagal response with bradycardia and occasionally hypotension.
